Candidatus Dehalogenimonas loeffleri is a recently discovered, anaerobic, Gram-negative bacterium that belongs to the phylum Chloroflexi. It is a member of the Dehalococcoidia class, a group of bacteria known for their ability to perform organohalide respiration, a process in which they use halogenated organic compounds as terminal electron acceptors during their energy-producing metabolism.

Candidatus Dehalogenimonas loeffleri was first identified in sediment samples collected from a chlorinated solvent-contaminated aquifer. It is capable of reductively dechlorinating a range of chlorinated ethenes, such as tetrachloroethene (PCE) and trichloroethene (TCE), which are common groundwater contaminants. This dechlorination process is an important bioremediation strategy for the cleanup of environments polluted with these harmful compounds.

The genome of Candidatus Dehalogenimonas loeffleri has been partially sequenced, revealing genes associated with organohalide respiration and other metabolic functions. However, due to its slow growth and difficulty in cultivation, much about the physiology and ecology of this bacterium remains to be elucidated through further research.
